paragraph.content: The Center may, in its discretion, utilize a neutral arbitration body and develop policies and procedures to resolve allegations of sexual abuse within its jurisdiction to determine the opportunity of any amateur athlete, coach, trainer, manager, administrator, or official, who is the subject of such an allegation, to participate in amateur athletic competition.

paragraph.heading: Preservation of rights.—
paragraph.content: Nothing in this section shall be construed as altering, superseding, or otherwise affecting the right of an individual within the Center’s jurisdiction to pursue civil remedies through the courts for personal injuries arising from abuse in violation of the Center’s policies and procedures, nor shall the Center condition the participation of any such individual in a proceeding described in paragraph (1) upon an agreement not to pursue such civil remedies.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: Except as provided in paragraph (2), an applicable entity shall not be liable for damages in any civil action for defamation, libel, slander, or damage to reputation arising out of any action or communication, if the action arises from the execution of the responsibilities or functions described in this section, section 220542, or section 220543.

paragraph.heading: Exception.—
paragraph.content: Paragraph (1) shall not apply in any action in which an applicable entity acted with actual malice, or provided information or took action not pursuant to this section, section 220542, or section 220543.

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.content: Any civil action brought in a State court against the Center relating to the responsibilities of the Center under this section, section 220542, or section 220543, shall be removed, on request by the Center, to the district court of the United States in the district in which the action was brought, and such district court shall have original jurisdiction over the action without regard to the amount in controversy or the citizenship of the parties involved.

subparagraph.heading: Rule of construction.—
subparagraph.content: Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to create a private right of action.

paragraph.heading: Definition of applicable entity.—
paragraph.chapeau: In this subsection, the term “applicable entity” means—

subparagraph.content: the Center;
a national governing body;
the corporation;
an amateur sports organization or other person sanctioned by a national governing body under section 220525;
an amateur sports organization reporting under section 220530;
any officer, employee, agent, or member of an entity described in subparagraph (A), (B), (C), (D), or (E); and
any individual participating in a proceeding pursuant to this section.

subsection.heading: Training Materials.—
subsection.chapeau: The office for education and outreach referred to in subsection (a)(1)(C) shall—

paragraph.content: develop training materials for specific audiences, including coaches, trainers, doctors, young children, adolescents, adults, and individuals with disabilities; and
not less frequently than every 3 years, update such training materials.

paragraph.heading: Prohibition with respect to former employees and board members.—
paragraph.content: A former employee or board member of the corporation or a national governing body shall not work or volunteer at the Center during the 2-year period beginning on the date on which the former employee or board member ceases employment with the corporation or national governing body.

heading.inline: Athletes serving on board of directors of national governing body.—

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.content: An athlete serving on the board of directors of a national governing body who is not otherwise employed by the national governing body, may volunteer at, or serve in an advisory capacity to, the Center.

subparagraph.heading: Ineligibility for employment.—
subparagraph.content: An athlete who has served on the board of directors of a national governing body shall not be eligible for employment at the Center during the 2-year period beginning on the date on which the athlete ceases to serve on such board of directors.

paragraph.heading: Conflicts of interest.—
paragraph.content: An executive or attorney for the Center shall be considered to have an inappropriate conflict of interest if the executive or attorney also represents the corporation or a national governing body.

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.content: The corporation and the national governing bodies shall not interfere in, or attempt to influence the outcome of, an investigation.

subparagraph.heading: Report.—
subparagraph.content: In the case of an attempt to interfere in, or influence the outcome of, an investigation, not later than 72 hours after such attempt, the Center shall submit to the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation of the Senate and the Committee on Energy and Commerce and the Committee on the Judiciary of the House of Representatives a report describing the attempt.

clause.heading: In general.—
clause.chapeau: Any decision, report, memorandum, work product, notes, or case file of the Center—

subclause.content: shall be confidential; and
shall not be subject to discovery, subpoena, or any other means of legal compulsion in any civil action in which the Center is not a party to the action.

clause.heading: Rule of construction.—
clause.content: Nothing in this subparagraph shall be construed to prohibit the Center from providing work product described in clause (i) to a law enforcement agency for the purpose of assisting in a criminal investigation.

subparagraph.heading: Fiscal year 2021.—
subparagraph.content: On January 4, 2021, the corporation shall make a mandatory payment of $20,000,000 to the Center for operating costs of the Center for fiscal year 2021.

subparagraph.heading: Subsequent fiscal years.—
subparagraph.content: For fiscal year 2022 and each fiscal year thereafter, the corporation shall make a mandatory payment of $20,000,000 to the Center not later than the close of business on the first regular business day in January.

paragraph.heading: Funds from national governing bodies.—
paragraph.content: The corporation may use funds received from 1 or more national governing bodies to make a mandatory payment required by paragraph (1).

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.content: The Center may file a lawsuit to compel payment under paragraph (1).

subparagraph.heading: Penalty.—
subparagraph.content: For each day of late or incomplete payment of a mandatory payment under paragraph (1) after January 1 of the applicable year, the Center shall be allowed to recover from the corporation an additional $20,000.

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.content: Amounts transferred to the Center by the corporation or a national governing body shall be used, in accordance with section 220503(15), primarily for the purpose of carrying out the duties and requirements under sections 220541 through 220543 with respect to the investigation and resolution of allegations of sexual misconduct, or other misconduct, made by amateur athletes.

clause.heading: In general.—
clause.chapeau: Of the amounts made available to the Center by the corporation or a national governing body in a fiscal year for the purpose described in section 220503(15)—

subclause.content: not less than 50 percent shall be used for processing the investigation and resolution of allegations described in subparagraph (A); and
not more than 10 percent may be used for executive compensation of officers and directors of the Center.

subclause.heading: In general.—
subclause.content: If, after the Center uses the amounts as allocated under clause (i), the Center does not use the entirety of the remaining amounts for the purpose described in subparagraph (A), the Center may retain not more than 25 percent of such amounts as reserve funds.

subclause.heading: Return of funds.—
subclause.content: The Center shall return to the corporation and national governing bodies any amounts, proportional to the contributions of the corporation and national governing bodies, that remain after the retention described in subclause (I).

clause.heading: Lobbying and fundraising.—
clause.content: Amounts made available to the Center under this paragraph may not be used for lobbying or fundraising expenses.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.chapeau: Not less frequently than annually, the Center shall carry out an audit of the corporation and each national governing body—

subparagraph.content: to assess compliance with policies and procedures developed under this subchapter; and

to ensure that consistent training relating to the prevention of child abuse is provided to all staff of the corporation and national governing bodies who are in regular contact with amateur athletes and members who are minors subject to parental consent.

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.content: The Center may impose on the corporation or a national governing body a corrective measure to achieve compliance with the policies and procedures developed under this subchapter or the training requirement described in paragraph (1)(B).

subparagraph.heading: Inclusions.—
subparagraph.content: A corrective measure imposed under subparagraph (A) may include the implementation of an athlete safety program or specific policies, additional compliance audits or training, and the imposition of a probationary period.

clause.heading: In general.—
clause.chapeau: On request by the Center, the corporation shall—

subclause.content: enforce any corrective measure required under subparagraph (A); and
report the status of enforcement with respect to a national governing body within a reasonable timeframe.

clause.heading: Methods.—
clause.content: The corporation may enforce a corrective measure through any means available to the corporation, including by withholding funds from a national governing body, limiting the participation of the national governing body in corporation events, and decertifying a national governing body.

clause.heading: Effect of noncompliance.—
clause.content: If the corporation fails to enforce a corrective measure within 72 hours of a request under clause (i), the Center may submit to the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation of the Senate and the Committee on Energy and Commerce and the Committee on the Judiciary of the House of Representatives a report describing the noncompliance.

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.content: Not less frequently than annually, the Center shall submit to Congress a report on the findings of the audit under paragraph (1) for the preceding year and the status of any corrective measures imposed as a result of the audit.

clause.heading: In general.—
clause.content: Each report under subparagraph (A) shall be made available to the public.

clause.heading: Personally identifiable information.—
clause.content: A report made available to the public shall not include the personally identifiable information of any individual.

subsection.heading: Reports to Corporation.—
subsection.chapeau: Not later than 30 days after the end of each calendar quarter that begins after the date of the enactment of the Empowering Olympic, Paralympic, and Amateur Athletes Act of 2020, the Center shall submit to the corporation a statement of the following:

paragraph.content: The number and nature of misconduct complaints referred to the Center, by sport.
The number and type of pending misconduct complaints under investigation by the Center.
The number of misconduct complaints for which an investigation was terminated or otherwise closed by the Center.
The number of such misconduct complaints reported to law enforcement agencies by the Center for further investigation.
The number of discretionary cases accepted or declined by the Center, by sport.
The average time required for resolution of such cases and misconduct complaints.

Information relating to the educational activities and trainings conducted by the office of education and outreach of the Center during the preceding quarter, including the number of educational activities and trainings developed and provided.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: Not later than 180 days after the end of a fiscal year, the Comptroller General of the United States shall make available to the public a certification relating to the Center’s independence from the corporation.

paragraph.heading: Elements.—
paragraph.chapeau: A certification required by paragraph (1) shall include the following:

subparagraph.content: A finding of whether a violation of a prohibition on employment of former employees or board members of the corporation under subsection (f) has occurred during the year preceding the certification.
A finding of whether an executive or attorney for the Center has had an inappropriate conflict of interest during that year.
A finding of whether the corporation has interfered in, or attempted to influence the outcome of, an investigation by the Center.
Any recommendations of the Comptroller General for resolving any potential risks to the Center’s independence from the corporation.

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.content: The Comptroller General may take such reasonable steps as, in the view of the Comptroller General, are necessary to be fully informed about the operations of the corporation and the Center.

subparagraph.heading: Specific authorities.—
subparagraph.chapeau: The Comptroller General shall have—

clause.content: access to, and the right to make copies of, any and all nonprivileged books, records, accounts, correspondence, files, or other documents or electronic records, including emails, of officers, agents, and employees of the Center or the corporation; and
the right to interview any officer, employee, agent, or consultant of the Center or the corporation.

subparagraph.heading: Treatment of privileged information.—
subparagraph.content: If, under this subsection, the Comptroller General seeks access to information contained within privileged documents or materials in the possession of the Center or the corporation, the Center or the corporation, as the case may be, shall, to the maximum extent practicable, provide the Comptroller General with the information without compromising the applicable privilege.

subsection.heading: In General.—
subsection.chapeau: The Center shall—

paragraph.content: develop training, oversight practices, policies, and procedures for implementation by a national governing body to prevent the abuse, including emotional, physical, and sexual abuse, of any amateur athlete; 1

paragraph.chapeau: include in the policies and procedures developed under section 220541(a)(3)— 2

subparagraph.chapeau: a requirement that all adult members of a national governing body or a facility under the jurisdiction of a national governing body, and all adults authorized by such members to interact with an amateur athlete, report immediately any allegation of child abuse of an amateur athlete who is a minor to—

clause.content: law enforcement consistent with section 226 of the Victims of Child Abuse Act of 1990 (34 U.S.C. 20341); and
the Center, whenever such members or adults learn of facts leading them to suspect reasonably that an amateur athlete who is a minor has suffered an incident of child abuse;

subparagraph.content: a requirement that the Center shall immediately report to law enforcement consistent with section 226 of the Victims of Child Abuse Act of 1990 (34 U.S.C. 20341) any allegation of child abuse of an amateur athlete who is a minor, including any report of such abuse submitted to the Center by a minor or by any person who is not otherwise required to report such abuse;

1 or more policies that prohibit any individual who is an employee, contractor, or agent of the Center from assisting a member or former member in obtaining a new job (except for the routine transmission of administrative and personnel files) if the individual knows that such member or former member violated the policies or procedures of the Center related to sexual misconduct or was convicted of a crime involving sexual misconduct with a minor in violation of applicable law;

subparagraph.chapeau: a requirement that the Center, including any officer, agent, attorney, or staff member of the Center, shall not take any action to notify an alleged perpetrator of abuse of an amateur athlete of any ongoing investigation or accusation unless—

clause.content: the Center has reason to believe an imminent hazard will result from failing to so notify the alleged perpetrator; or

subclause.content: authorizes the Center to take such action; or
declines or fails to act on, or fails to respond to the Center with respect to, the allegation within 72 hours after the time at which the Center reports to law enforcement under subparagraph (B);

subparagraph.content: a mechanism, approved by a trained expert on child abuse, that allows a complainant to report easily an incident of child abuse to the Center, a national governing body, law enforcement authorities, or other appropriate authorities;

reasonable procedures to limit one-on-one interactions, including communications, between an amateur athlete who is a minor and an adult (who is not the minor’s legal guardian) at a facility under the jurisdiction of a national governing body without being in an observable and interruptible distance from another adult, except under emergency circumstances;

subparagraph.chapeau: procedures to prohibit retaliation by the corporation or any national governing body against any individual who makes—

clause.content: a report under subparagraph (A) or (E); or
any other report relating to abuse of any amateur athlete, including emotional, physical, and sexual abuse;

subparagraph.content: oversight procedures, including regular and random audits conducted by subject matter experts unaffiliated with, and independent of, a national governing body to ensure that policies and procedures developed under that section are followed correctly and that consistent training is offered and given to all adult members who are in regular contact with amateur athletes who are minors, and subject to parental consent, to members who are minors, regarding prevention of child abuse;

subparagraph.chapeau: a mechanism by which a national governing body can—

clause.content: share confidentially a report of suspected child abuse of an amateur athlete who is a minor by a member of a national governing body or an adult authorized by a national governing body or an amateur sports organization to interact with an amateur athlete who is a minor, with the Center, which in turn, may share with relevant national governing bodies and other entities; and
withhold providing to an adult who is the subject of an allegation of child abuse authority to interact with an amateur athlete who is a minor until the resolution of such allegation;

subparagraph.chapeau: a prohibition on the use in a decision of the Center under section 220541(a)(1)(D) of any evidence relating to other sexual behavior or the sexual predisposition of the alleged victim, or the admission of any such evidence in arbitration, unless the probative value of the use or admission of such evidence, as determined by the Center or the arbitrator, as applicable, substantially outweighs the danger of—

clause.content: any harm to the alleged victim; and
unfair prejudice to any party; and

subparagraph.content: training for investigators on appropriate methods and techniques for ensuring sensitivity toward alleged victims during interviews and other investigative activities.

subsection.heading: Rule of Construction.—
subsection.content: Nothing in this section shall be construed to limit the ability of a national governing body to impose an interim measure to prevent an individual who is the subject of an allegation of sexual abuse from interacting with an amateur athlete prior to the Center exercising its jurisdiction over a matter.

subsection.heading: Records.—
subsection.content: The Center shall keep correct and complete records of account.

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.chapeau: Not less frequently than annually, the financial statements of the Center for the preceding fiscal year shall be audited by an independent auditor in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles—

clause.content: to ensure the adequacy of the internal controls of the Center; and
to prevent waste, fraud, or misuse of funds transferred to the Center by the corporation or the national governing bodies.

subparagraph.heading: Location.—
subparagraph.content: An audit under subparagraph (A) shall be conducted at the location at which the financial statements of the Center normally are kept.

subparagraph.heading: Report.—
subparagraph.content: Not later than 180 days after the date on which an audit under subparagraph (A) is completed, the independent auditor shall issue an audit report.

clause.heading: In general.—
clause.content: On completion of the audit report under subparagraph (C) for a fiscal year, the Center shall prepare, in a separate document, a corrective action plan that responds to any corrective action recommended by the independent auditor.

clause.heading: Matters to be included.—
clause.chapeau: A corrective action plan under clause (i) shall include the following for each such corrective action:

subclause.content: The name of the person responsible for the corrective action.
A description of the planned corrective action.
The anticipated completion date of the corrective action.

In the case of a recommended corrective action based on a finding in the audit report with which the Center disagrees, or for which the Center determines that corrective action is not required, an explanation and a specific reason for noncompliance with the recommendation.

paragraph.heading: Access to records and personnel.—
paragraph.content: With respect to an audit under paragraph (1), the Center shall provide the independent auditor access to all records, documents, and personnel and financial statements of the Center necessary to carry out the audit.

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.chapeau: The Center shall make available to the public on an easily accessible internet website of the Center—

clause.content: each audit report under paragraph (1)(C);
the Internal Revenue Service Form 990 of the Center for each year, filed under section 501(c) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986; and
the minutes of the quarterly meetings of the board of directors of the Center.

subparagraph.heading: Personally identifiable information.—
subparagraph.content: An audit report or the minutes made available under subparagraph (A) shall not include the personally identifiable information of any individual.

paragraph.heading: Rule of construction.—
paragraph.content: For purposes of this subsection, the Center shall be considered a private entity.

subsection.heading: Report.—
subsection.chapeau: The Center shall submit an annual report to Congress, including—

paragraph.content: a strategic plan with respect to the manner in which the Center shall fulfill its duties under sections 220541 and 220542;
a detailed description of the efforts made by the Center to comply with such strategic plan during the preceding year;
any financial statement necessary to present fairly the assets, liabilities, and surplus or deficit of the Center for the preceding year;
an analysis of the changes in the amounts of such assets, liabilities, and surplus or deficit during the preceding year;

paragraph.chapeau: a detailed description of Center activities, including—

subparagraph.content: the number and nature of misconduct complaints referred to the Center;
the total number and type of pending misconduct complaints under investigation by the Center;
the number of misconduct complaints for which an investigation was terminated or otherwise closed by the Center; and
the number of such misconduct complaints reported to law enforcement agencies by the Center for further investigation;

paragraph.chapeau: a detailed description of any complaint of retaliation made during the preceding year by an officer or employee of the Center or a contractor or subcontractor of the Center that includes—

subparagraph.content: the number of such complaints; and
the outcome of each such complaint;

paragraph.content: information relating to the educational activities and trainings conducted by the office of education and outreach of the Center during the preceding year, including the number of educational activities and trainings developed and provided; and
a description of the activities of the Center.

subsection.heading: Definitions.—
subsection.chapeau: In this section—

paragraph.chapeau: “audit report” means a report by an independent auditor that includes—

subparagraph.content: an opinion or a disclaimer of opinion that presents the assessment of the independent auditor with respect to the financial records of the Center, including whether such records are accurate and have been maintained in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles;
an assessment of the internal controls used by the Center that describes the scope of testing of the internal controls and the results of such testing; and
a compliance assessment that includes an opinion or a disclaimer of opinion as to whether the Center has complied with the terms and conditions of subsection (b); and

paragraph.content: “independent auditor” means an independent certified public accountant or independent licensed public accountant, certified or licensed by a regulatory authority of a State or a political subdivision of a State, who meets the standards specified in generally accepted accounting principles.

subchapter.heading: DISSOLUTION OF BOARD OF DIRECTORS OF CORPORATION AND TERMINATION OF RECOGNITION OF NATIONAL GOVERNING BODIES

section.heading: Definitions
section.chapeau: In this subchapter, the term “joint resolution” means a joint resolution—

paragraph.content: which does not have a preamble; and

paragraph.chapeau: for which—

clause.content: the title is only as follows: “A joint resolution to dissolve the board of directors of the United States Olympic and Paralympic Committee”; and

clause.chapeau: the matter after the resolving clause—

subclause.content: is as follows: “That Congress finds that dissolving the board of directors of the United States Olympic and Paralympic Committee would not unduly interfere with the operations of chapter 2205 of title 36, United States Code”; and

prescribes adequate procedures for forming a board of directors of the corporation as expeditiously as possible and in a manner that safeguards the membership and voting power of the representatives of amateur athletes at all times, consistent with the membership and voting power of amateur athletes under section 220504(b)(2); or

clause.content: the title is only as follows: “A joint resolution relating to terminating the recognition of a national governing body”; and

the matter after the resolving clause is only as follows: “That Congress determines that _________, which is recognized as a national governing body under section 220521 of title 36, United States Code, has failed to fulfill its duties, as described in section 220524 of title 36, United States Code”, the blank space being filled in with the name of the applicable national governing body.

section.heading: Dissolution of board of directors of corporation and termination of recognition of national governing bodies

subsection.heading: Dissolution of Board of Directors of Corporation.—
subsection.content: Effective on the date of enactment of a joint resolution described in section 220551(2)(A) with respect to the board of directors of the corporation, such board of directors shall be dissolved.

subsection.heading: Termination of Recognition of National Governing Body.—
subsection.content: Effective on the date of enactment of a joint resolution described in section 220551(2)(B) with respect to a national governing body, the recognition of the applicable amateur sports organization as a national governing body shall cease to have force or effect.
